alert.note: Alert for Washington (Vermont) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Burlington (Northern Vermont and New York)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued July 11 at 12:26PM EDT until July 12 at 2:00AM EDT by NWS Burlington
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Vermont... Winooski River At Montpelier affecting Washington County. For the Winooski River...including Moretown, Montpelier, Waterbury, Essex Junction...Major flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL JUST AFTER MIDNIGHT TONIGHT... * WHAT...Major flooding is occurring. * WHERE...Winooski River at Montpelier. * WHEN...Until just after midnight tonight. * IMPACTS...Downtown Montpelier will continue to be inundated, and local roads will be covered by water until the level drops below 18 feet. Route 2 and railroad tracks along the river will continue to be covered with water, and widespread field flooding will continue throughout the Winooski River valley. Below 18 feet, Route 2 will continue flood at Bailey Avenue bridge, as well as the entrance to the Montpelier High School, parking lots behind state office buildings next to the river, and low lying fields and farmland will continue to be inundated. These impacts will remain until the stage falls below 15 feet. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:45 AM EDT Tuesday the stage was 20.5 feet. - Bankfull stage is 15.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 11:45 AM EDT Tuesday was 21.4 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 20.5 feet this afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage late this evening. - Flood stage is 15.0 feet. - Flood History...The observed maximum river stage of 21.4 feet is the 2nd highest crest in history. This is higher than what was observed during Tropical Storm Irene where the stage reached 19.05 feet on 8/29/2011, but still well shy of the 1927 flood which reached 27.1 feet on 11/03/1927. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued late tonight at 200 AM EDT.
